topics.title: Webvan: The Grocery Delivery Dream That Came Too Soon

hook.text: In 1999, Webvan raised $375M to deliver groceries to your door. It was the future of shopping.

buildup.text: They built massive warehouses, hired thousands, and expanded to eight cities in 18 months.

discovery.text: The problem? Online grocery demand barely existed. Only 1% of Americans had ever ordered food online.

twist.text: Webvan burned through $830M in just two years. They scaled a service almost nobody wanted yet.

climax.text: By 2001, Webvan was bankrupt. A decade later, Instacart proved the idea rightâ€”with perfect timing.

punchline.text: The idea wasn't wrong. The calendar was.

quiz.question: Why did Webvan fail despite having a good concept?
options: They scaled massively before consumer demand for online groceries existed
Their delivery technology was unreliable and broke constantly
Grocery stores sued them out of business

topics.title: Google Glass: The Future Nobody Was Ready For

hook.text: In 2013, Google launched Glassâ€”smart glasses that put a computer on your face. Tech reviewers raved.

buildup.text: Early adopters wore them to bars and restaurants. People called them 'Glassholes' behind their backs.

discovery.text: Google underestimated something no spec sheet measures: social acceptability.

twist.text: Restaurants banned them. Movie theaters banned them. Even Google's own cafeteria felt awkward.

climax.text: Google shelved Glass in 2015. The technology worked fine. Society wasn't ready to be recorded 24/7.

punchline.text: Great tech fails when it ignores human comfort.

quiz.question: What was the primary reason Google Glass failed as a consumer product?
options: The hardware was too expensive to manufacture at scale
Society wasn't ready to accept being constantly recorded by others
The display resolution was too low to be useful

topics.title: Quibi: The $1.75 Billion Content Disaster

hook.text: Jeffrey Katzenberg raised $1.75B for Quibiâ€”short premium videos designed for phones. Hollywood lined up.

buildup.text: They hired A-list talent. Steven Spielberg signed on. Every episode was under ten minutes.

discovery.text: Quibi launched in April 2020â€”the month the world locked down and free content exploded on TikTok.

twist.text: People stuck at home didn't want short clips on tiny screens. They wanted long shows on big TVs.

climax.text: Quibi shut down after six months, returning $350M to investors. The fastest billion-dollar failure ever.

punchline.text: No amount of money can buy good timing.

quiz.question: What doomed Quibi's launch in April 2020?
options: Their app had too many technical bugs to function properly
A pandemic kept people home where they preferred long-form content on big screens
They couldn't secure enough celebrity talent for their shows

topics.title: Segway: The Most Overhyped Product in History

hook.text: Before its 2001 launch, Segway was hyped as bigger than the internet. Steve Jobs compared it to the PC.

buildup.text: Inventor Dean Kamen predicted cities would be redesigned around Segways. The media went berserk.

discovery.text: The Segway worked exactly as promised. It just solved a problem most people didn't actually have.

twist.text: At $5,000 each, only mall cops and tourists bought them. Kamen predicted 10,000 a weekâ€”they sold 30,000 total.

climax.text: The company sold for a fraction of its investment. Its new owner died riding a Segway off a cliff.

punchline.text: Hype and product-market fit are not the same thing.

quiz.question: What was the core reason the Segway failed commercially?
options: The technology didn't work as advertised
It solved a problem most people didn't have, at a price they wouldn't pay
Government regulations banned it from public roads

topics.title: Friendster: First Doesn't Mean Winner

hook.text: Friendster launched in 2002â€”a full year before MySpace and two years before Facebook. It had the idea first.

buildup.text: Within months, three million users signed up. Friendster was the world's first viral social network.

discovery.text: But the servers couldn't handle the traffic. Pages took 20 seconds to load. Users raged and left.

twist.text: Instead of fixing the tech, Friendster sued competitors and deleted fake profiles that users loved.

climax.text: MySpace and Facebook ate its lunch. Friendster pivoted to gaming in Asia and quietly disappeared.

punchline.text: Being first means nothing if you can't keep up.

quiz.question: Why did Friendster lose to MySpace and Facebook despite launching first?
options: They couldn't handle traffic, had slow servers, and alienated users by deleting profiles
They were blocked by internet providers in the United States
Their design was copied exactly by both MySpace and Facebook

topics.title: Jawbone: Death by a Thousand Pivots

hook.text: Jawbone raised $930M from top investorsâ€”more than Uber or Airbnb did at similar stages.

buildup.text: They started with Bluetooth speakers, then pivoted to fitness trackers to chase the Fitbit craze.

discovery.text: Each pivot burned cash without building loyalty. Customers never knew what Jawbone actually stood for.

twist.text: Their fitness tracker had so many defects that class-action lawsuits piled up faster than sales.

climax.text: Jawbone liquidated in 2017 with zero return to investors. Nearly a billion dollars vanished entirely.

punchline.text: Pivoting without focus is just expensive wandering.

quiz.question: What was the fundamental mistake that destroyed Jawbone?
options: They pivoted repeatedly without building brand identity or fixing quality issues
They refused to pivot and stayed with their original Bluetooth speaker
A single lawsuit bankrupted the entire company overnight

topics.title: MoviePass: The All-You-Can-Watch Meltdown

hook.text: MoviePass offered unlimited movie tickets for $9.95 a month. A single ticket already cost $15.

buildup.text: Subscribers exploded to three million. Every movie fan in America signed up practically overnight.

discovery.text: MoviePass paid full price for every ticket. They lost money on almost every single customer.

twist.text: Their plan was to collect viewing data and sell it to studios. No studio was willing to pay for it.

climax.text: MoviePass burned through $40M per month. The stock price dropped from $32 to two cents.

punchline.text: Losing money on every customer doesn't scale. It speeds up death.

quiz.question: Why did MoviePass's business model collapse?
options: Movie theaters refused to accept MoviePass tickets
They paid full price per ticket while charging far less, and their data monetization plan failed
A competing service undercut their already low prices

topics.title: Solyndra: The Green Energy Money Pit

hook.text: Solyndra got a $535M government loan to build solar panels. President Obama visited the factory himself.

buildup.text: Their cylindrical solar panels looked revolutionary. The engineering was genuinely clever.

discovery.text: While Solyndra perfected fancy tubes, Chinese manufacturers slashed flat-panel prices by 70%.

twist.text: Solyndra's panels cost six times more than the competition. No amount of innovation fixed that.

climax.text: They filed for bankruptcy in 2011. The FBI raided the offices. Taxpayers lost over half a billion.

punchline.text: Clever technology still has to compete on price.

quiz.question: What ultimately killed Solyndra despite its innovative technology?
options: Government regulators shut down their manufacturing process
Their panels couldn't generate enough electricity to be useful
Chinese competitors made conventional solar panels far cheaper than Solyndra's fancy design

topics.title: Better Place: Electric Cars Without Enough Cars

hook.text: Better Place raised $850M to build battery-swapping stations for electric cars across entire countries.

buildup.text: Founder Shai Agassi convinced Israel and Denmark to be pilot markets. The vision was breathtaking.

discovery.text: They built swap stations before enough compatible cars existed. Only Renault made one model that fit.

twist.text: Each station cost $500K to build. They built dozens, but only 1,000 cars were ever on the road.

climax.text: Better Place burned $850M and sold fewer cars than a single Tesla showroom. They shut down in 2013.

punchline.text: Infrastructure without adoption is just expensive scenery.

quiz.question: What was the fatal flaw in Better Place's strategy?
options: Their battery-swapping technology didn't work reliably
They built expensive infrastructure before enough compatible cars existed to use it
Electric car drivers preferred charging at home to swapping batteries

topics.title: Quirky: Crowdsourced Products, Crowdsourced Failure

hook.text: Quirky let everyday people submit inventions and voted on which ones to manufacture. It raised $185M.

buildup.text: They launched new products every single weekâ€”from egg separators to smart air conditioners.

discovery.text: Speed killed quality. Most products had razor-thin margins and sky-high return rates.

twist.text: Quirky spent more on marketing each product than they earned selling it. The math never worked.

climax.text: They filed for bankruptcy in 2015 owing $170M. Only two of hundreds of products ever turned a profit.

punchline.text: Quantity is not a substitute for product-market fit.

quiz.question: Why did Quirky's model of launching a new product every week fail?
options: Users stopped submitting inventions after the first year
Most products had thin margins and high return rates, and marketing costs exceeded revenue
They couldn't find manufacturers willing to produce small batches

topics.title: Juicero: The $400 Juice Bag Squeezer

hook.text: Juicero sold a $400 WiFi-connected juicer backed by $120M in venture capital. Silicon Valley loved it.

buildup.text: The machine pressed proprietary juice packs with four tons of force. It was beautifully engineered.

discovery.text: A Bloomberg reporter squeezed the juice packs by hand and got the same result in 90 seconds.

twist.text: The internet erupted. A $400 machine that did what bare hands could do became a global meme overnight.

climax.text: Juicero shut down five months after the article. It became the poster child for Silicon Valley excess.

punchline.text: Sometimes the disruption is just squeezing a bag.

quiz.question: What revealed that Juicero's $400 machine was unnecessary?
options: A reporter discovered the juice packs could be squeezed by hand just as easily
The machine broke down after a week of normal use
An independent lab found the juice contained no real nutrients

topics.title: Amazon Fire Phone: When Even Bezos Gets It Wrong

hook.text: In 2014, Jeff Bezos revealed the Fire Phone with a gimmicky 3D face-tracking display.

buildup.text: Amazon spent four years and hundreds of millions developing it in total secrecy.

discovery.text: The 3D feature drained the battery fast and served no useful purpose. Reviewers were baffled.

twist.text: AT&T exclusivity locked out most customers. Amazon priced it at $199â€”same as the far superior iPhone.

climax.text: Amazon wrote off $170M in unsold Fire Phones. The product was killed within a year of launch.

punchline.text: Even geniuses build things nobody needs.

quiz.question: What was the fundamental problem with the Amazon Fire Phone?
options: It was too expensive to manufacture at a profit
Its key featureâ€”3D face trackingâ€”was a gimmick that drained battery and added no value
Amazon couldn't get enough apps on its app store

topics.title: Google+: The Social Network Nobody Wanted

hook.text: Google launched Google+ in 2011, forcing two billion Gmail users to create profiles they never asked for.

buildup.text: Google threw its best engineers at the problem and tied Google+ into YouTube comments and app reviews.

discovery.text: Users created accounts because Google forced them to, then never posted a single thing.

twist.text: Internally, Google rewarded employees for Google+ integration, warping every product around it.

climax.text: A data breach exposed 500,000 accounts in 2018. Google used it as the excuse to finally shut it down.

punchline.text: You can't force people to be social.

quiz.question: Why did Google+ fail despite Google's massive resources?
options: The technology was too slow and buggy compared to Facebook
Forcing users to create profiles didn't generate real engagementâ€”people ignored it
Facebook sued Google for copying their design

topics.title: Microsoft Zune: The iPod Killer That Couldn't

hook.text: Microsoft launched the Zune in 2006 to kill the iPod. It was brown. That told you everything.

buildup.text: The Zune actually had a great feature: wireless sharing. You could beam songs to nearby Zunes.

discovery.text: Shared songs self-destructed after three plays. Microsoft turned a cool feature into a frustration.

twist.text: Apple launched the iPhone a year later, making all dedicated music players obsolete overnight.

climax.text: Microsoft discontinued Zune in 2011. It sold 2 million units. The iPod had sold 400 million.

punchline.text: Copying a product is not the same as understanding it.

quiz.question: What undermined the Zune's best featureâ€”wireless song sharing?
options: The wireless range was too short to be practical
Shared songs self-destructed after three plays, ruining the experience
Apple blocked Zune from syncing with iTunes libraries

topics.title: Color Labs: $41 Million for an App Nobody Understood

hook.text: Color Labs raised $41M before even launching. It was one of the largest pre-launch raises in history.

buildup.text: The app let people share photos with strangers nearby. Investors bet big on the social proximity trend.

discovery.text: Nobody understood what Color was for. Users opened it, looked around confused, and deleted it.

twist.text: Color pivoted three times in one yearâ€”photo sharing to group video to something nobody remembers.

climax.text: Apple quietly bought Color's patents for $7M. Investors lost over $30M on a product nobody used.

punchline.text: Money can't solve a problem that doesn't exist.

quiz.question: What was the root cause of Color Labs' failure?
options: A competitor launched the same app first and captured the market
The app solved no clear problemâ€”users couldn't understand its purpose
Their photo quality was too low compared to Instagram

topics.title: Twitter's Four Founders: The War for Credit

hook.text: Twitter had four co-founders who all claimed to be the real creator. The truth was messier than any tweet.

buildup.text: Jack Dorsey sent the first tweet. Ev Williams ran the company. Noah Glass built the first prototype.

discovery.text: Noah Glass named it 'Twitter' and built the first versionâ€”then was fired and erased from the story.

twist.text: Dorsey and Williams fought over the CEO role. The board fired one, then the other, then rehired Dorsey.

climax.text: The infighting paralyzed Twitter for years. Facebook grew 10x while Twitter's founders fought each other.

punchline.text: Four founders. Zero alignment. A decade of chaos.

quiz.question: How did co-founder conflict harm Twitter's growth?
options: Infighting over the CEO role paralyzed the company while competitors raced ahead
The founders split the company into four competing products
They spent all the company's money on legal battles with each other

topics.title: Zipcar: The Founder Who Got Pushed Out

hook.text: Robin Chase co-founded Zipcar and invented modern car-sharing. The board fired her two years later.

buildup.text: Chase built Zipcar from scratchâ€”sourcing cars, writing software, and recruiting the first 500 members.

discovery.text: The board decided a passionate founder wasn't the same as a CEO who could scale a company.

twist.text: Her replacement grew Zipcar to an IPO and a $500M acquisition by Avis. Chase got a fraction of the value.

climax.text: Chase watched the company she built become a billion-dollar brand without her name attached to it.

punchline.text: Building the rocket doesn't mean you get to fly it.

quiz.question: Why was Zipcar co-founder Robin Chase removed from her own company?
options: She committed financial fraud that the board discovered
The board believed a different leader was needed to scale the company beyond its startup phase
She voluntarily left to start a competing car-sharing service

topics.title: Eduardo Saverin: The Facebook Co-Founder Diluted to Zero

hook.text: Eduardo Saverin put up the first $19,000 for Facebook. Zuckerberg diluted his stake from 34% to 0.03%.

buildup.text: Saverin was CFO and Zuckerberg's best friend. He funded the servers that kept early Facebook alive.

discovery.text: When Sean Parker joined, he restructured the company. Saverin's shares were diluted to almost nothing.

twist.text: Saverin sued and settled for an estimated $1B. But his original stake would be worth over $60B today.

climax.text: Saverin renounced his U.S. citizenship and moved to Singapore. The friendship was permanently destroyed.

punchline.text: In startups, handshake deals are worth nothing.

quiz.question: What happened to Eduardo Saverin's original 34% stake in Facebook?
options: He sold it voluntarily to fund his own startup
It was diluted to 0.03% through a corporate restructuring he didn't agree to
Facebook bought it back at a fair market price

topics.title: Snapchat's Third Founder: Erased From History

hook.text: Reggie Brown says he invented Snapchat's disappearing photos. Spiegel and Murphy say he's lying.

buildup.text: Brown sketched the original concept in their Stanford dorm. All three worked on the first prototype.

discovery.text: Once the app gained traction, Spiegel and Murphy locked Brown out of the servers and ghosted him.

twist.text: Brown sued for a third of the company. He settled for $157.5Mâ€”a fortune, but a sliver of Snap's billions.

climax.text: Brown signed an NDA. He can never publicly tell his full story. His name was scrubbed from history.

punchline.text: The price of a missing contract: billions of dollars.

quiz.question: What lesson does Reggie Brown's experience with Snapchat teach founders?
options: Never share your idea with anyone until you have a patent
Always have a formal legal agreement before building anything with co-founders
It's better to work alone than with co-founders

topics.title: The Winklevoss Twins vs. Zuckerberg: The Idea War

hook.text: Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss hired Zuckerberg to build their social network. He built his own instead.

buildup.text: The twins had the concept for HarvardConnection. Zuckerberg delayed their project while coding Facebook.

discovery.text: By the time the twins realized what happened, Facebook had thousands of users and venture capital.

twist.text: They sued and settled for $65M in Facebook stock. They invested it all in Bitcoin and became billionaires.

climax.text: The lawsuit reshaped startup law forever. Courts now take idea-theft claims far more seriously.

punchline.text: Hiring the wrong person can create your biggest competitor.

quiz.question: What did the Winklevoss twins do with their $65M Facebook settlement?
options: They started a competing social network that eventually failed
They invested it all in Bitcoin and became billionaires
They donated it to Harvard's computer science program

topics.title: Pets.com: The Sock Puppet That Ate $300 Million

hook.text: Pets.com had a famous sock puppet mascot in a Super Bowl ad. The company lasted exactly 268 days after IPO.

buildup.text: They sold pet food online at prices below cost to grab market share, planning to raise prices later.

discovery.text: Shipping 30-pound bags of dog food cost more than the food itself. Every single sale lost money.

twist.text: Instead of fixing the economics, they spent $17M on marketingâ€”including that infamous Super Bowl ad.

climax.text: Pets.com went from IPO to liquidation in 268 days. The sock puppet was sold to a car loan company.

punchline.text: The mascot outlived the company. That says everything.

quiz.question: What was the core economic problem that killed Pets.com?
options: They couldn't attract enough customers to their website
Shipping heavy pet food cost more than the product itself, so every sale lost money
Pet stores sued them for unfair competition

topics.title: WeWork: The $47 Billion Illusion

hook.text: Adam Neumann convinced SoftBank that WeWork was a tech company. It was actually a landlord with beer.

buildup.text: WeWork signed long-term leases, added couches and kombucha, then charged startups premium weekly rent.

discovery.text: Neumann trademarked the word 'We' and charged his own company $5.9M to license it back.

twist.text: The IPO filing revealed WeWork lost $1.9B in one year. SoftBank's $47B valuation collapsed to $8B.

climax.text: Neumann was pushed out with a $1.7B exit package. Thousands of employees lost their jobs and equity.

punchline.text: Charisma is not a business model.

quiz.question: What did WeWork's IPO filing reveal that caused its valuation to collapse?
options: The company had been lying about its number of members
Massive losses of $1.9B in a single year and questionable self-dealing by the CEO
Their office buildings had major safety violations

topics.title: Theranos: The Biggest Fraud in Silicon Valley

hook.text: Elizabeth Holmes claimed Theranos could run 200 blood tests from a single finger prick. It couldn't.

buildup.text: Theranos raised $700M and hit a $9B valuation. Holmes was on the cover of every major magazine.

discovery.text: The machines didn't work. Theranos secretly ran most tests on standard commercial lab equipment.

twist.text: Whistleblowers went to journalist John Carreyrou. Holmes threatened to sue anyone who talked.

climax.text: Holmes was convicted of fraud and sentenced to over 11 years in prison. The company was a total lie.

punchline.text: Fake it till you make it has a legal limit.

quiz.question: How did Theranos hide the fact that its technology didn't work?
options: They only tested healthy patients who would always get normal results
They secretly ran most blood tests on standard commercial lab equipment instead of their own machines
They hired doctors to manually check and correct every result

topics.title: Groupon: The Fastest Decline From IPO Glory

hook.text: Groupon turned down Google's $6B acquisition offer. Two years later, it was worth less than $2B.

buildup.text: Daily deals felt magical at first. Millions of consumers hunted for half-price restaurant coupons.

discovery.text: Merchants lost money on every deal. Customers came for discounts once and never returned full-price.

twist.text: Groupon went public at a $13B valuationâ€”then restated its earnings because the accounting was wrong.

climax.text: The stock dropped 80% within a year. Founder Andrew Mason was fired by email and blogged about it.

punchline.text: Growth without retention is just a very loud death.

quiz.question: Why did Groupon's daily deal model ultimately fail?
options: Consumers stopped using coupons entirely as the economy improved
Merchants lost money on deals and discount customers never returned at full price
Google launched a competing daily deal service that stole all their users

topics.title: Fab.com: From $1 Billion to $15 Million in Two Years

hook.text: Fab.com was the fastest e-commerce site to hit a $1B valuation. Two years later it sold for $15M.

buildup.text: They sold designer goods through flash sales. Ten million users joined and investors poured in $336M.

discovery.text: Fab expanded to Europe, hired 700 people, and opened warehousesâ€”all before proving unit economics.

twist.text: Return rates hit 30%. Customer acquisition costs soared. Every new market bled cash faster.

climax.text: Fab pivoted five times, laid off 80% of staff, and was quietly acquired for pennies on the dollar.

punchline.text: Scaling losses doesn't build a business. It accelerates failure.

quiz.question: What was Fab.com's critical mistake during its rapid growth phase?
options: They expanded globally and hired aggressively before proving their unit economics worked
They switched from flash sales to a subscription model that users hated
Their website was hacked and customer data was stolen

topics.title: Slack: Born From the Ashes of a Failed Video Game

hook.text: Slack started as a chat tool inside a video game company called Tiny Speck. The game completely flopped.

buildup.text: The game, Glitch, was strange and charming but attracted too few players to survive.

discovery.text: While building Glitch, the team created an internal messaging tool. It was the best thing they ever made.

twist.text: Stewart Butterfield shut down the game and bet everything on the chat tool nobody outside had seen.

climax.text: Slack became the fastest SaaS product to hit a $1B valuation. Salesforce later bought it for $27.7B.

punchline.text: The best pivots come from tools you built for yourself.

quiz.question: How did Slack emerge from the failure of the game Glitch?
options: They sold the game's user data to fund a new messaging product
The internal communication tool they built while making the game turned out to be far more valuable
A venture capitalist forced them to abandon gaming entirely

topics.title: The Lean Startup: Learning to Fail Cheaply

hook.text: Eric Ries spent two years building a product nobody wanted. That painful mistake became a global movement.

buildup.text: His startup IMVU spent months perfecting features. When they finally launched, users were confused and left.

discovery.text: Ries realized they should have tested a rough version firstâ€”the minimum viable product was born.

twist.text: The Lean Startup book became Silicon Valley's bible. VCs started demanding MVPs before writing checks.

climax.text: Dropbox launched with a fake demo video. Zappos tested demand by buying shoes from stores and reselling.

punchline.text: The fastest way to succeed is to fail cheaply first.

quiz.question: What is the core principle of Eric Ries's Lean Startup methodology?
options: Spend as little money as possible on every aspect of the business
Test a minimum viable product with real users before building the full version
Launch with a perfect product to make a strong first impression

topics.title: Pre-Mortems: Predicting Failure Before It Happens

hook.text: Stripe holds 'pre-mortem' meetings where teams imagine a project has failed. Then they figure out why.

buildup.text: Most startups only analyze failure after it happens. By then, the lessons are buried under blame.

discovery.text: Studies show teams that predict failures in advance catch 30% more risks than teams that only react.

twist.text: Amazon's 'working backwards' method is a pre-mortem in disguiseâ€”they write the press release first.

climax.text: The best companies make failure analysis a habitâ€”ending every project with a learning review.

punchline.text: The autopsy before the patient dies is the smartest one.

quiz.question: What is a 'pre-mortem' in the context of startup planning?
options: A meeting where the team imagines the project has already failed and identifies why
A financial audit conducted before the company spends any money
A legal review of all contracts before launch day

topics.title: Pattern Recognition: Why Failed Founders Win Next Time

hook.text: Second-time founders succeed 30% more often than first-timersâ€”even if their previous startup failed.

buildup.text: Investors call it 'pattern recognition.' Failed founders learn what no textbook or MBA can teach.

discovery.text: They spot dying markets faster, fire bad hires sooner, and know exactly when to pivot or quit.

twist.text: Reid Hoffman failed with SocialNet before LinkedIn. Max Levchin failed twice before co-founding PayPal.

climax.text: Harvard research shows failure itself isn't the teacherâ€”the structured reflection afterward is.

punchline.text: Failure is only tuition if you study the lesson.

quiz.question: Why are second-time founders statistically more likely to succeed?
options: They have more money saved from their first company
Investors give them better deal terms out of sympathy
They develop pattern recognition from past failures that helps them avoid the same mistakes

topics.title: The Pivot Graveyard: When Giving Up the Idea Is the Idea

hook.text: YouTube started as a video dating site called 'Tune In, Hook Up.' Nobody uploaded dating videos.

buildup.text: The founders noticed people uploading random clips instead. They dropped the dating angle entirely.

discovery.text: Instagram began as Burbn, a check-in app. The only feature anyone used was photo sharing.

twist.text: Nintendo started as a playing card company. Nokia once made rubber boots. The first idea rarely survives.

climax.text: The greatest companies aren't loyal to their first idea. They're loyal to finding what actually works.

punchline.text: Stubbornness kills more startups than bad ideas do.

quiz.question: What do YouTube, Instagram, and Nintendo have in common?
options: They were all founded by the same group of investors
They all started as something completely different before pivoting to what made them famous
They all failed at least three times before finding success
